{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} The '''Anglo-Albanian Association''' is an association established in 1913 by [[Aubrey Herbert]] under the name ''Albanian Committee''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Elsie |first=Robert |title=1912 Aubrey Herbert: A Meeting with Isa Boletini |url=http://www.albanianhistory.net/texts20_1/AH1912_3.html |publisher=Robert Elsie |accessdate=10 August 2012 |quote=At the time of the Conference of Ambassadors in London in 1913, he founded an Albanian Committee |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022231544/http://www.albanianhistory.net/texts20_1/AH1912_3.html |archivedate=22 October 2012 }}</ref> In 1918 this committee evolved into ''Anglo-Albanian Society'' and then into the Anglo-Albanian Association.<ref>{{cite web|last=Elsie |first=Robert |title=1912 Aubrey Herbert: A Meeting with Isa Boletini |url=http://www.albanianhistory.net/texts20_1/AH1912_3.html |publisher=Robert Elsie |accessdate=10 August 2012 |quote=This Albanian Committee evolved into the Anglo-Albanian Society (1918), of which Herbert was president, and finally into the Anglo-Albanian Association. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022231544/http://www.albanianhistory.net/texts20_1/AH1912_3.html |archivedate=22 October 2012 }}</ref>
== Objectives == The Anglo-Albanian Association was founded to support the Albanian cause in [[Great Britain]] and to promote recognition of the [[Independent Albania]].<ref>{{Citation |last=Elsie |first=Robert|authorlink= Robert Elsie |title= Historical dictionary of Albania |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=haFlGXIg8uoC&pg=PA13 |accessdate= 4 February 2012 |year=2010 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |location=Lanham |isbn=978-0-8108-7380-3 |oclc=454375231 |page=13 }}</ref>
== Members == Some of the members were [[Edith Durham]], [[Lord Lamington]] and [[Dervish Duma]].<ref>{{Citation |last=Elsie |first=Robert |authorlink= Robert Elsie |title= Historical dictionary of Albania |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=haFlGXIg8uoC&pg=PA13 |accessdate= 4 February 2012 |year=2010 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |location=Lanham |isbn=978-0-8108-7380-3 |oclc=454375231 |page=14}}</ref>
After 1985 the Chairman of the Anglo-Albanian Association was [[Harry Hodgkinson (writer)|Harry Hodgkinson]], British writer, journalist, and naval [[intelligence officer]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://us.macmillan.com/author/harryhodgkinson | title = Harry Hodgkinson | first = | last = | authorlink = | coauthors = | date = | month = | year = 2008 | work = | publisher = Macmillan | location = United Kingdom | page = | pages = | at = |trans-title=| format = | doi = | accessdate = 27 November 2010 | quote = Harry Hodgkinson (1913–1994) was a writer, journalist, naval intelligence officer, Balkan expert and from 1985 Chairman of the Anglo-Albanian Association. | ref = | separator = | postscript = }}</ref> Its current president is [[Noel Malcolm]].<ref>{{Citation |last=Elsie |first=Robert|authorlink= Robert Elsie |title= Historical dictionary of Albania |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=haFlGXIg8uoC&pg=PA13 |accessdate= 4 February 2012 |year=2010 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |location=Lanham |isbn=978-0-8108-7380-3 |oclc=454375231 |page=14}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.anglo-albanian.org.uk/ Website of the Anglo-Albanian Association]
[[Category:United Kingdom friendship associations]] [[Category:Albania friendship associations]] [[Category:1913 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1913]] [[Category:Albania–United Kingdom relations]]
{{Albania-stub}} {{UK-org-stub}}

The '''anti-bureaucratic revolution''' was a campaign of street protests by supporters of Serbian leader [[Slobodan Milošević]] that ran between 1988 and 1989 in [[Yugoslavia]]. The protests overthrew the governments of the Serbian autonomous provinces of [[Socialist Autonomous Province of Vojvodina|Vojvodina]] and [[Socialist Autonomous Province of Kosovo|Kosovo]], as well as the government of the [[Socialist Republic of Montenegro]], and replaced them with allies of Milošević, thereby creating a dominant voting bloc within the [[Presidency of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav presidency council]]. The name ''anti-bureaucratic revolution'' is derived from the proclaimed revolt against bureaucratic and [[political corruption|corrupt governing structures]]. The events were condemned by the [[communist]] governments of the western Yugoslav republics (especially [[Socialist Republic of Slovenia|SR Slovenia]] and [[Socialist Republic of Croatia|SR Croatia]]), who successfully resisted the attempts to expand the revolt onto their territories, and turned against Milošević. The rising antagonism eventually resulted in the dissolution of the ruling [[League of Communists of Yugoslavia]] in 1990, and subsequently in the [[breakup of Yugoslavia]]. ==Prelude== {{expert needed| reason=Institutional access required to verify source in this section|talk=Prelude: Milošević's rise to power |date=January 2016}} Since the adoption of the 1974 Constitution of Yugoslavia, Serbia and its two autonomous provinces Kosovo and Vojvodina entered into political deadlock with the provincial governments in Kosovo and Vojvodina.{{sfn|Jović|2008|p=172}} In 1976 the Serbian government issued its first complaints of unconstitutional practice of autonomy by the provinces to Tito and [[Edvard Kardelj]] and issued a subsequent complaint in 1984 on the matter, attempting to resolve the problems within the 1974 Constitution.{{sfn|Jović|2008|pp=173-174}} It was reported that the provinces had repeatedly denied the Serbian government the ability to enact policies in their territories, such as regulation of citizenship policy, common defense law, and [[Social policy|social plans]].{{sfn|Jović|2008|p=174}} The situation in Kosovo became a crisis in the [[1981 protests in Kosovo]] by Albanians who were heard shouting slogans such as "We are Albanians, not Yugoslavs", "Kosova Republic", "Unity with Albania", "Long live Marxism-Leninism, Down with Revisionism" and others.{{sfn|Jović|2008|p=185}} The presence of ethnic and ideological dimensions to the protestors demands led to Yugoslav authorities deciding to forcibly stop the protests, the president of the Pristina League of Communists, Aslan Fazlia (an Albanian) said that the protests were nationalistic and counterrevolutionary and announced tough police action against the demonstrators.{{sfn|Jović|2008|p=185}} This action failed to quell the protests that instead grew in response with protests by Albanians sweeping across Kosovo, the President of the League of Communists of Kosovo [[Mahmut Bakalli]] decided in response to ask the [[Yugoslav People's Army]] (JNA) to bring tanks onto the streets.{{sfn|Jović|2008|p=185}} Police reinforcements from [[Central Serbia]] were stopped by a roadblock and then Albanian demonstrators took hostages from thirty-four houses of Serbs and Montenegrins, demanding that these police forces leave Kosovo in exchange for the release of the hostages.{{sfn|Jović|2008|pp=185-186}} Only after additional police forces from Pristina arrived were the hostages released.{{sfn|Jović|2008|pp=185-186}} The protests lead to vandalism throughout Kosovo including smashed windows of cars, shops, and state institutions.{{sfn|Jović|2008|pp=185-186}} The Yugoslav leadership declared a "crisis situation in Kosovo" and all republics were requested to send their police troops to Kosovo.{{sfn|Jović|2008|pp=185-186}} The Yugoslav leadership was shocked by extent of the violence used by the demonstrators and the relatively large participation in the demonstrations.{{sfn|Jović|2008|pp=185-186}} The aftermath of the 1981 protests in Kosovo resulted in resentment by Serbs in Kosovo to the political situation in Kosovo.{{sfn|Crampton|2013|p=148}} Serbs suspected that deliberate [[Albanianization]] of Kosovo and Serbs being driven out was demonstrated by statistics showing that the population of Serbs in Kosovo had significantly decreased from 23.5% in 1961 to 13.2% in 1981, as well as making claims that they were being persecuted by Albanians including that Serb women were being systematically raped by Albanians.{{sfn|Crampton|2013|p=148}} Many of these claims were not backed up by factual evidence but built up as popular rumours believed amongst Serbs in Kosovo.{{sfn|Crampton|2013|p=148}} Milošević took control of the [[League of Communists of Yugoslavia]]'s [[League of Communists of Serbia|Serbian branch]] in September 1987, when his faction won over its opposition, led by [[Ivan Stambolić]]. His rise to power coincided with Serbo-Albanian tensions in [[Kosovo]], as [[Serbs of Kosovo|Kosovo Serbs]] felt oppressed by [[Albanians in Kosovo|Albanians]] and the Albanian-dominated leadership of the province. The tensions were further boosted by inflammatory reports in the Serbian media. According to the [[1974 Yugoslav Constitution|1974 Yugoslav constitution]], the two [[autonomous province]]s of Serbia ([[Vojvodina]] and Kosovo) were largely independent from the central Serbian government, with both of them holding a seat in the Yugoslav Presidency, on a par with the six constituent republics of Yugoslavia. In effect, their status was almost equivalent to the republics', which enabled provincial leaderships of Kosovo and Vojvodina to have policies that were practically independent. In late 1987 and 1988, a populist campaign started in Serbia against this situation, which it described as untenable. Provincial leaderships were being accused of bureaucratic inefficiency and alienation from the people. Popular slogans like "Oh Serbia in three parts, you will be whole again" (Ој Србијо из три дела поново ћеш бити цела, ''oj Srbijo iz tri dela ponovo ćeš biti cela''){{cite web|url=http://www.nin.co.rs/arhiva/2431/1.html|title=Duh Belog dvora|publisher=[[NIN (magazine)|NIN]]|date=1997-08-01|author=Petar Ignja|language=Serbian}} caught on. The atmosphere was further stirred up by numerous articles and readers' letters in Serbian press, the most notorious being ''[[Politika]]'''s rubric "Odjeci i reagovanja" (''Echoes and reactions''), a [[letters to the editor]] column which was used as a type of [[astroturfing]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GkBmdCwHuDsC&pg=PA550&lpg=PA550&dq=anti-bureaucratic+revolution |title=Politika in the Storm of Nationalism|author=Aleksandar Nenadović|year=1993|publisher=Central European University Press|isbn=978-963-9116-56-6}}{{sfn|Milosavljević|2003}} The main points of the campaign were the following:{{cite journal|url=http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/1467-923X.00201|title=Western Intervention and the Promotion of Democracy in Serbia|author=Ian Kearns|publisher=The Political Quarterly|pages=23|year=1999|volume=70|issue=1|issn=0032-3179|doi=10.1111/1467-923X.00201|journal=The Political Quarterly }} *Serbs in Kosovo were being harassed by Albanians and suppressed by the Albanian-dominated Kosovo government *Due to the 1974 constitution, Serbia had no effective control over its provinces, whose leaderships were bureaucratic and estranged from the people *This constitution was created by the influence of the other Yugoslav republics, especially Slovenia and Croatia, in order to suppress Serbia's power and create an environment for the exploitation of Serbia's natural resources *The constitution had, in effect, created a [[confederal]] type of government, as no decision could be made without the [[consensus]] of all six republics in the federal parliament; and a system with a better consideration of popular majority was called for (the slogan "[[one man, one vote]]" was one of the most popular) *Therefore, a thorough revision of the federal constitution and the enhancement of Serbian control over its provinces were necessary ==Protests== The mass protests started in February 1986, with several meetings of Kosovo Serbs in [[Belgrade]] and in Kosovo, pleading for a resolution of the problematic situation on Kosovo. These were relatively small, with 100-5,000 participants, and were mostly reactions to individual inter-ethnic incidents. The largest such protest was held in [[Kosovo Polje]] in April 1987, gathering around 20,000 people.{{sfn|Milosavljević|2003}} However, the outburst of protests began in the latter half of 1988. In June, the protest of workers of the [[Zmaj (factory)|Zmaj]] factory gathered 5,000 protestors; in July, meetings were held in seven towns with tens of thousands protesters, and in August in ten towns with 80,000 people. By September they spread to 39 towns with over 400,000 people.{{sfn|Milosavljević|2003}} ===Vojvodina (October 1988)=== On 5 October 1988, around 150,000 people gathered in [[Novi Sad]] to protest against the Vojvodina provincial government. The gathering started a day earlier in the nearby town of [[Bačka Palanka]], and, as ''Politika'' explained it, people spontaneously gathered and moved on to Novi Sad, the provincial capital.{{sfn|Milosavljević|2003}} The protest in Bačka Palanka was led by [[Mihalj Kertes]], a mid-level official of the Communist Party, an ethnic [[Hungarians in Vojvodina|Hungarian]] who would later become famous for his remark "How can you Serbs be afraid of Serbia when I, a Hungarian, am not afraid of Serbia?"{{cite web|title=Crash of Yugoslavia's Money Man| url=http://listserv.buffalo.edu/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind0011&L=justwatch-l&O=D&P=77111|author=Michael Dobbs|publisher=Washington Post Foreign Service|date=2000-11-29}} (and later still, as Milošević's money man). Protesters from Novi Sad and other parts of Serbia gathered in huge numbers, and began the protest in front of the provincial [[Parliament of Vojvodina]]. The provincial leadership, led by [[Milovan Šogorov]], [[Boško Krunić]] and [[Živan Berisavljević]], were caught by surprise. Before the event, they tried to compromise and negotiate with Milošević, expressing cautious support for the constitutional changes while trying to keep their and Vojvodina's position intact. However, the avalanche of media campaign orchestrated from Belgrade was about to overwhelm them; they were labelled as power-hungry "[[Armchair revolutionary|armchair]]ers" (фотељаши / ''foteljaši'') and "autonomists" (аутономаши / ''autonomaši'').{{cite web|title=Vojvodina:Užegli jogurt|date=1998-10-15|url=http://www.nin.co.rs/arhiva/2494/6.html|author=Petar Ignja|publisher=NIN|language=Serbian}} The Vojvodina government then cut off power and water supply to protesters, a move which enraged them further still, and caused even more people from Novi Sad and its vicinity to join. When power was restored, they tried a different tactic: in order to cheer the demonstrators up, they gave them bread and [[yogurt]]. However, thousands of yogurt packages were soon thrown at the Parliament building by angry protesters. That term "Yogurt Revolution" for the protest was named after that episode.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aENQit9KT0sC&pg=RA2-PA354&lpg=RA2-PA354&dq=Yogurt+revolution+Novi+Sad| title=Serbia Since 1989: Politics And Society Under Milosevic And After (pp 350-379)|author=Emil Kerenji|editor=[[Sabrina Petra Ramet]]|publisher=University of Washington Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-295-98538-1}} On October 6, the entire collective leadership of Vojvodina resigned and were soon replaced with Milošević's men of trust [[Nedeljko Šipovac]], Radovan Pankov and [[Radoman Božović]]. The Vojvodina representative in the Central Committee of [[League of Communists of Yugoslavia|SKJ]], Boško Krunić, resigned and was replaced by Stanko Radmilović, while the President of the Central Committee of the [[League of Communists of Vojvodina|SKV]], Milovan Šogorov, resigned and was replaced by Bogosav Kovačević. ===Ušće rally=== The rally in [[Belgrade]], at [[Ušće]] (the large field at confluence of [[Sava|Sava River]] into [[Danube]]) was held on November 19, 1988. According to the state press, it gathered about a million people, and according to others, several hundred thousands. It was conceived as a "mother of all rallies", and a huge crowd of people come from all parts of Serbia by public and factory buses taken just for this opportunity. Milošević reaffirmed his and Serbia's confinement to the principles of liberty and Serbian equity within Yugoslavia:{{cite web|url=http://www.beograd.rs/cms/view.php?id=201267|title=Disintegration Years 1988-2000|publisher=Assembly of Belgrade}}
We will win the battle for [[Kosovo]] regardless of the obstacles placed in front of us in the country and abroad. So, we will win regardless of the uniting of our enemies from abroad and those in the country. And that this nation will win the battle for freedom, is a fact well-known even to the [[Ottoman Empire|Turkish]] and [[Nazi Germany|German]] conquerors.
===Montenegro=== Rallies and media were also similarly used in Montenegro with the first rally in support of Kosovo Serbs and Kosovo Montenegrins taking place in [[Titograd]] on 20 August 1988.{{cite news | url = http://www.dan.co.me/?nivo=3&datum=2009-08-23&rubrika=Politika&najdatum=2009-08-21&clanak=198303 | title = Bili Srbi, a sada ih svrbi | newspaper = [[Dan (newspaper)|Dan]] | date = August 21, 2009 | accessdate = 2010-06-07}} The leadership of the [[League of Communists of Montenegro|Montenegrin Communist League]] was on the defense at the time, claiming that it was protecting Kosovo, but their restraint in direct support for Milošević was deemed not good enough by the putschists. What eventually proved to be the coup's first act occurred on 7 October 1988 when Montenegrin police intervened against protesters in Žuta Greda demanding resignations from the Montenegrin leadership. In order to deal with the situation the leadership proclaimed the [[state of emergency]]. The state of emergency did not last long, as it was taken as an act of hostility towards Serbia by media outlets controlled by Milošević as well as Milošević's supporters in Montenegro.{{cite web|title=Serbian President: The Technology Of A Showdown|url=http://www.scc.rutgers.edu/serbian_digest/153/t153-3.htm|publisher=Vreme|author=Milan Milošević, Filip Švarm|date=1994-08-29}} The second act started with joint rallies consisting of workers from Radoje Dakić, a state-owned factory, and [[Veljko Vlahović University]] students. On 10 January 1989, over 10,000 protesters gathered in [[Titograd]].{{sfn|Milosavljević|2003}} The old leadership, confused and disorganised, soon gave in; none of them later played a significant political role. The new "young lions" of the Montenegro, [[Momir Bulatović]], [[Milo Đukanović]] and [[Svetozar Marović]], became the new leadership, strongly allied with Milošević in the years to come. The League of Communists of Montenegro was subsequently transformed by the "triumvirate" who had full control over the (Socialist) Republic of Montenegro into the [[Democratic Party of Socialists of Montenegro]], which vigorously maintained its grip over Montenegro and does so to this day more than 20 years later. ===Toppling of Kosovar leadership and reduction of autonomy=== [[Azem Vllasi]] and [[Kaqusha Jashari]], the two top-ranked Kosovo politicians, were replaced in November 1988.{{sfn|Milosavljević|2003}} The Albanian population of Kosovo grew restless, and in February 1989 they engaged in a general strike, particularly manifesting itself in the [[1989 Kosovo miners' strike]]. Meanwhile, on February 28, another major rally was held in Belgrade, where the chants "We want weapons" and "Arrest Vllasi" were heard, and three days later, Vllasi was indeed placed under arrest.{{sfn|Milosavljević|2003}} In early 1989, the [[Parliament of Serbia]] had proposed constitutional amendments that would have significantly reduced SAP Kosovo's autonomous status within SR Serbia.{{sfn|Krieger|2001|p=522}} Kosovo Albanians organized large demonstrations against these moves,{{sfn|Krieger|2001|p=522}} but in March 1989, preceding a final push for the ratification of constitutional changes in the Assembly of Kosovo, the Yugoslav police rounded up around 240 prominent Kosovo Albanians, apparently selected based on their anti-ratification sentiment, and detained them with complete disregard for [[due process]].{{sfn|Anderson|1990|pp=27–29}} Albanian representatives in the [[Parliament of Kosovo]] boycotted the vote on the matter on March 23, 1989, but regardless of the failure of the motion to meet the required two-thirds majority, it was declared to have passed.{{sfn|Krieger|2001|p=522}} On March 28, the Serbian parliament approved the constitutional changes.{{sfn|Krieger|2001|p=522}} ===Gazimestan rally=== {{Main article|Gazimestan speech}} The largest rally of all was held at [[Gazimestan]] on 28 June 1989, gathering two million according to ''[[Politika]]''.{{sfn|Milosavljević|2003}} ===Action North=== When a "Rally of Truth" ({{lang-sl|Miting resnice}}) was attempted in [[Ljubljana]], [[Socialist Republic of Slovenia|SR Slovenia]] in December 1989, in an action named '''Action North''' Slovene police forces prevented it with the help of Croatian police forces. This action can be considered the first Slovenian defense action against the attacks of the supporters of Milošević, leading to Slovenian independence.{{cite web|url=http://www.fvv.uni-mb.si/varstvoslovje/Abstract.aspx?cid=329 |title=Historical Circumstances in Which "The Rally of Truth" in Ljubljana Was Prevented |publisher=Journal of Criminal Justice and Security |accessdate=4 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213053210/http://www.fvv.uni-mb.si/varstvoslovje/Abstract.aspx?cid=329 |archivedate=December 13, 2013 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.rtvslo.si/osamosvojitev/prispevek/108/predvajaj/|title="Rally of truth" (Miting resnice)|publisher= A documentary published by [[RTV Slovenija]]|accessdate=4 July 2012}} The members of Slovene police forces who participated later organized their own veteran organization.{{cite web |url=http://www.akcijasever.si/|title=akcijasever.si|publisher=The "North" Veteran Organization|accessdate=3 July 2012}} ==Aftermath== The anti-bureaucratic revolution affected the balance of power in the [[Presidency of Yugoslavia]]. Serbia's [[Borisav Jović]] (at the time the President of the Presidency), Montenegro's Nenad Bućin, Vojvodina's Jugoslav Kostić and Kosovo's [[Riza Sapunxhiu]], started to form a voting bloc. The reduction of provincial autonomy, but not the complete abolishment of provincial status, was seen as intentional, as Milošević needed the extra provincial votes to gain influence in the federal presidency.{{cite book|last=Krieger|first=Heike|title=The Kosovo Conflict and International Law: An Analytical Documentation 1974–1999|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-OhPTJn8ZWoC&pg=PA522|accessdate=9 March 2012|date=12 July 2001|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521800716|page=522}}{{cite book|last=Judah|first=Tim|title=Kosovo: what everyone needs to know|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M2IbzZcAnUUC&pg=PP56|accessdate=9 March 2012|date=29 September 2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195376739|page=56}} In August 1990 the [[Croatian Parliament]] replaced its representative [[Stipe Šuvar]] with [[Stjepan Mesić]] in the wake of the [[Log Revolution]],{{cite web | url = http://www.slobodnaevropa.org/content/article/1045346.html | publisher = [[Radio Free Europe]] | language = Croatian | title = Svjedoci raspada - Stipe Šuvar: Moji obračuni s njima | date = 2008-02-27 | accessdate = 2012-11-27}} but Mesić was only seated in October 1990 because of protests from the Serbian side. From then on, Mesić joined Macedonia's [[Vasil Tupurkovski]], Slovenia's [[Janez Drnovšek]] and Bosnia and Herzegovina's [[Bogić Bogićević]] in opposing the demands to proclaim a general [[state of emergency]], which would have allowed the [[Yugoslav People's Army]] to impose [[martial law]] in March 1991. When Sapunxhiu 'defected' his faction in the final vote, Jović briefly resigned and returned, Bućin was replaced with [[Branko Kostić]], and Sapunxhiu with [[Sejdo Bajramović]], effectively deadlocking the Presidency.{{cite news | url = http://www.bhdani.com/arhiva/208/t20801.shtml | language = Bosnian | newspaper = [[BH Dani]] | title = Stjepan Mesić, svjedok kraja (I) - Ja sam inicirao sastanak na kojem je podijeljena Bosna | date = 2001-06-01 | issue = 208 | accessdate = 2012-11-27}} Soon the country descended into the [[Yugoslav Wars]]. ==See also== *[[Serbia in the Yugoslav Wars]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d5np99Vgc0YC&pg=PA165&lpg=PA165&dq=anti-bureaucratic+revolution |title=The Destruction of Yugoslavia: tracking the break-up 1980-92 (pp 165-170)|author=Branka Magaš|year=1993|publisher=Verso|isbn=978-0-86091-593-5}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-OhPTJn8ZWoC&pg=PA522|title=The Kosovo Conflict and International Law: An Analytical Documentation 1974-1999|year=2001|first=Heike|last=Krieger|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521800716}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|title=Yugoslavia, Crisis in Kosovo: A Report from Helsinki Watch and the International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights | first = Kenneth | last = Anderson | publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]] | year = 1990 | isbn = 9780929692562 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TCb8RDy7q-IC&pg=PA28}} * {{cite book | ref = harv | first = Dejan | last = Jović | title = Yugoslavia: A State that Withered Away | publisher = Purdue University | year = 2008 | isbn = 9781557534958}} * {{cite book | ref = harv | first = R. J. | last = Crampton | title = The Balkans Since the Second World War | publisher = Routledge | year = 2013 | isbn = 9781317891161}} * {{cite book | ref = harv | url = http://www.cpi.hr/download/links/7292.pdf | chapter = Antibirokratska revolucija 1987-1989. godine | language = Serbian | first = Olivera | last = Milosavljević | format=PDF | title = Dijalog povjesničara - istoričara 8, Zadar | editor-last1 = Graovac | editor-first1 = Igor | editor-last2 = Fleck | editor-first2 = Hans-Georg | publisher = Political Science Research Centre Ltd. (PSRC) for Scientific Research Work / Zaklada Friedrich-Naumann | location = Zagreb, Croatia | date = 2003 | accessdate = 2013-02-23 | isbn = 953-6922-06-1}} {{refend}} [[Category:1980s in Montenegro]] [[Category:Breakup of Yugoslavia]] [[Category:History of Kosovo]] [[Category:20th century in Vojvodina]] [[Category:Political history of Montenegro]] [[Category:Political history of Serbia]] [[Category:Political history of Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Protests in Montenegro]] [[Category:Protests in Serbia]] [[Category:Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Serb rebellions]] [[Category:Serbian nationalism in Kosovo]] [[Category:Serbian nationalism in Montenegro]] [[Category:Yugoslav Serbia]] [[Category:Revolutions of 1989]]

page.title: Association for the Defense of Nature

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Conservation organisations to [[:Category:Conservation organizations]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name = Associació per a la Defensa de la Natura {{ca icon}}
Association for the Defense of Nature |logo = Logo adn.jpg |logo_size = 125px |vector_logo = [[File:Logo adn.jpg|centre|125px]] |type = [[Non-governmental organization]] |founded_date = 1986 |founder = |first president = |location_city = |location_country ={{AND}} |location = [[Andorra la Vella]] |area_served = {{AND}} |origins = |key_people = |focus = [[Environmentalism]] |method = |revenue = |num_volunteers = |owner = |Non-profit_slogan = |homepage = [http://www.adn-andorra.org/ adn-andorra.org] |dissolved = |footnotes = }} '''The Association for the Defense of Nature (ADN)''' was born in 1986 as a result of the concern of a group of people for the environment. It is an [[NGO]] that aims to protect and study nature in [[Andorra]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bondia.ad/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4656&Itemid=999 |title=ADN organitza una projecció de fotografies del sud-est d'Àsia |work=Diari Bondia Andorra |date=2009-04-20 |accessdate=2011-04-23 |language=ca}} The ADN pursues its aims through three basic lines of action: conservation, study and information. == Conservation == ADN carries out direct action of nature conservation: * Promotes planning to streamline the human presence (industrial, tourism, etc..) In the Valleys of Andorra. * Work for the creation of protected natural areas, suggesting areas, management measures, ways of sustainable use, etc.. * Vigil for the safeguarding of endangered species, both animal and vegetable. * Claim effective solutions to the problems of pollution and waste. * Collaborate with other institutions to create, adapt and apply the laws of environmental protection. == Study == ADN contributes to research on the environment and this protection: * Promotes and develops scientific basis for conservation actions and proposals. * Learn lesser known natural elements of our country, analyzing the situation and proposing measures for their protection.{{cite web |url=http://www.unesco.ad/imagenes/publicacions/butlleti13.pdf |title=La petjada ecològica d'Andorra: càlcul i educació ambiental |work=UNESCO Andorra |year=2005 |accessdate=2011-04-23 |language=ca}} == Information == The ADN is to discover and appreciate nature and therefore: * Organizers: Check educational tours to the mountain and protected natural areas Conferences, symposia and debates. Shares of environmental education with a solid scientific basis, in coordination with other institutions.{{cite web |url=http://www.bondia.ad/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5853:adn-obre-el-debat-entre-el-jovent-sobre-lalt-nivell-dinsostenibilitat&catid=43:societat |title=ADN obre el debat entre el jovent sobre l'alt nivell d'insostenibilitat |work=Diari Bondia Andorra |date=2009-06-10 |accessdate=2011-04-23 |language=ca}} * Edit and spreads: Informative publications on the natural heritage of Andorra and the need to preserve it. The periodical "Aigüerola". == Collaboration == It is affiliate to [[BirdLife International]].{{cite web |url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/national/andorra/index.html |title=L'Associació per a la Defensa de la Natura is the BirdLife Affiliate |work=Birdlife International |date= |accessdate=2011-04-23 }} BirdLife is the most important world organization for the study and protection of birds and their habitats.{{cite web |url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/index.html |title=About BirdLife |work=Birdlife International |date= |accessdate=2011-04-23 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110514003940/http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/index.html| archivedate= 14 May 2011 | deadurl= no}} Maintains contact and exchanges with many international organizations with similar objectives.{{cite web |url=http://www.paysdelours.com/fr/pour-un-plan-global-de-restauration-et-de-cohabitation-avec-l-ours-dans-les-pyrenees.html?cmp_id=50&news_id=737 |title=Pour un plan global de restauration et de cohabitation avec l'ours dans les Pyrénées |work=Pays de l'ours |date=2010-05-11 |accessdate=2011-04-23 |language=fr}}{{cite news |url=http://www.pyreneesinfo.fr/actu/pyrenees-les-pro-ours-se-retrouvent-en-andorre |title=Les pro-ours se retrouvent en Andorre |work=Pyrénéesinfo.fr |date=2010-05-11 |accessdate=2011-04-23 |language=fr |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323024922/http://www.pyreneesinfo.fr/actu/pyrenees-les-pro-ours-se-retrouvent-en-andorre/ |archive-date=2012-03-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Participates and organizes symposia and international conferences.{{cite web |url=http://www.unesco.ad/imagenes/biodiversitat.pdf |title=2010 Any Internacional de la Diversitat Biològica - Programa d’activitats |work=UNESCO Andorra |date=2010-05-08 |accessdate=2011-04-23 |language=ca}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.adn-andorra.org}} {{Andorra topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Association For The Defense Of Nature (Adn) In Andorra}} [[Category:Conservation organizations]] [[Category:Environment of Andorra]] [[Category:Organisations based in Andorra]] [[Category:Pyrenees]] [[Category:Environmental organizations established in 1986]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Andorra]] {{Andorra-stub}}

[[Elín Björg Jónsdóttir]], chairman |website= [http://www.bsrb.is www.bsrb.is] |footnotes= }} The '''BSRB''' (formerly '''Bandalag Starfsmanna Ríkis og Bæja''') or '''Confederation of State and Municipal Employees of Iceland''' is a [[federation]] of [[trade union]] in [[Iceland]]. It was formed in 1942 and is the largest federation of employees in the public sector in Iceland with 25 member unions with over 21,000 members in total. About two in every three members are women. The BSRB is affiliated with the [[International Trade Union Confederation]], the [[European Trade Union Confederation]], the [[Council of Nordic Trade Unions]] and [[Public Services International]]. ==References== *{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al., | edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7 }} ==External links== * [http://www.bsrb.is www.bsrb.is] {{Is icon}} {{Portal|Organized labour}} [[Category:Trade unions in Iceland]] [[Category:International Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:European Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:Council of Nordic Trade Unions]] [[Category:Public Services International]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1942]] [[Category:1942 establishments in Iceland]] {{Europe-trade-union-stub}} {{Iceland-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Identity document | document_name = East German passport | image = DDR Reisepass.jpg | image_caption = East German passport. | date_first_issued = | using_jurisdiction = {{flag|East Germany}} | valid_jurisdictions = | document_type = [[Passport]] | purpose = Identification | eligibility = [[East German nationality law|East German citizenship]] | expiration = }} The '''East German passport''' was issued to citizens of the former German Democratic Republic (commonly known as [[East Germany]]) for international travel. Since the [[German reunification|reunification]] of Germany, all German citizens are issued [[German passport]]s.
== Overview == According to a ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' report in 1989, only 25% of East Germans were passport holders.<ref name="WaPo">{{cite news|last1=McCartney|first1=Robert J.|title=East Germany Opens Berlin Wall And Borders, Allowing Citizens To Travel Freely To The West|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1989/11/10/east-germany-opens-berlin-wall-and-borders-allowing-citizens-to-travel-freely-to-the-west/98a8e433-efba-44a9-bd42-0c6781375d66/|accessdate=10 January 2018|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=10 November 1989}}</ref>
According to an East German passport law in 1957, East German citizens needed a visa to travel abroad, including [[West Germany]] and [[West Berlin]].<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Kalinovsky|editor1-first=Artemy M.|editor2-last=Daigle|editor2-first=Craig|title=The Routledge Handbook of the Cold War|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-315-88228-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tpnAAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT137&lpg=PT137&dq=east+german+passport+law&source=bl&ots=Sd2GXryMoU&sig=YOjo7AYphD3FK12VG7BwsiqP29I&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj--qza-s7YAhUKzWMKHWh_DqIQ6AEIczAP#v=onepage&q=east%20german%20passport%20law&f=false}}</ref> The penalty for making an unauthorized journey outside East Germany was imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aftermath 1949 -- 1959|url=https://www.trumanlibrary.org/whistlestop/BERLIN_A/AFTERMAT.HTM|website=[[Harry S. Truman Presidential Library and Museum|Harry S. Truman Presidential Library & Museum]]|quote=1957: A new passport law provided for three years' imprisonment for anyone making an unauthorized journey outside the borders of East Germany...}}</ref>
Once they return from their travels, the passports needed to be turned in.<ref name="WaPo"/>
== Types of passports == There were at least four types of passports: alien, service, standard, and diplomatic.<ref name="PassportType">{{cite web|title=East German Passport Types|url=https://www.passport-collector.com/east-german-passport-types/|website=Passport-collector.com|accessdate=10 January 2018|date=20 August 2011}}</ref><ref name="PassportCollectorFact">{{cite web|title=The Passport of the German Democratic Republic (GDR)|url=https://www.passport-collector.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/GDR-passport-history.pdf|website=Passport-collector.com|accessdate=10 January 2018}}</ref>
While standard passports were blue in color, alien and service passports were in different shades of green.<ref name="PassportType"/> Diplomatic passports were in red.<ref name="PassportType"/><ref name="DailyMail">{{cite news|last1=Wilkinson|first1=James|title=From Stalin’s Soviet Union to East Germany and British Palestine: The extraordinary historical passports to countries that no longer exist - including a European state that lasted just four years|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4373648/See-passports-countries-no-longer-exist.html|accessdate=10 January 2018|date=2 April 2017}}</ref>
==Languages== East German passports contained text in German, French, English, and Russian.<ref name="PassportCollectorFact"/> English, however, was omitted from the passport after a revision in or around 1988.<ref name="PassportCollectorFact"/>
==Passport note==
East German passports contained a note to the effect that:
::''The Ministry of Foreign Affairs asks all authorities both inland and abroad to let the bearer of this passport travel freely and to grant him any protection and assistance that he might require.''<ref name="PassportCollectorFact"/>
Versions issued in late 1989 forward to the country's [[Die Wende|demise in October 1990]] omit the note.<ref name="PassportCollectorFact"/>
== Following reunification == Following reunification, the Unification Treaty provided that East German passports would remain in force until, at the latest, 31 December 1995.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paßgesetz der Deutschen Demokratischen Republik|url=http://www.verfassungen.de/de/ddr/passgesetz79.htm|accessdate=11 January 2018|language=[[German language|German]]|quote=Einigungsvertrag vom 31. August 1990 (BGBl. II S. 889) mit der Maßgabe, dass die ausgestellten Pässe bis spätestens zum 31. Dezember 1995 in Geltung bleiben}}</ref> After that date, East German passports were invalid for identification and citizens had to use [[German passport]]s.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Passports}}
[[Category:Government of East Germany]] [[Category:Defunct passports]] [[Category:Foreign relations of East Germany]]

The '''Flanders Institute for Logistics''' ({{lang-nl|Vlaams Instituut voor de Logistiek}}; VIL) is a [[Flanders|Flemish]] non-profit organization, founded in 2003 by the [[Flemish government]]. The VIL supports and enhances the competitiveness of the [[logistics]] sector in Flanders.

In [[Sweden]], a '''folkpark''' is a public recreation space, usually featuring large grassed areas, trees, children's play facilities, etc. Most towns and cities have a folkpark. These parks were originally created by the [[labour movement]] so that [[worker]]s and their families could have a place to unwind. In larger folkparks, there is sometimes a [[bandstand]] or stage, and they are used for concerts and other entertainment. Summer folkpark tours are a traditional part of the touring circuit for bands, etc.<ref>[http://www.folkpark.nu/index.htm Folkparker] ''folkpark.nu''. Retrieved: November 23, 2014.</ref>
==See also== *[[Folkets hus]] *[[Folkhemmet]]

Pascal Vugts | first_aired = 2002 | last_aired = Present | runtime = 47 minutes | camera = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | related = | language = Dutch | country = {{NED}} | website = http://www.gamekings.tv }} '''''Gamekings''''' is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] television program centered on [[videogames]] and is broadcast on [[Comedy Central]] in The Netherlands.{{cite web |url=http://www.comedycentral.nl/nieuws/69383-gamekings-komt-naar-comedy-central |title=Gamekings komt naar Comedy Central |date=19 March 2015 |website=Comedy Central |access-date=5 January 2016}} Until 2005 it was broadcast on the former Dutch television channel ''The Box'', until 2011 on [[TMF Nederland|TMF]] and until 2014 on [[MTV]]. Since then they have moved to SpikeTV and are now working under their own Label Blammo Media, additionally being sponsored by Fans with their 'Gamekings Premium' service. In the program the presenters give their opinion about new videogames, but you see them living the "gamer life" as well. The program was named the equivalent of '[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]' for games by Nieuwe Revu Magazine.{{citation |last1=Oosterwijk|first1=Geert|title=Top Gear, maar dan met games|magazine=Nieuwe Revu|date=October 2010|pages=30–31}} == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Dutch television talk shows]] {{Europe-tv-prog-stub}} {{Netherlands-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox bridge | bridge_name = Katima Mulilo Bridge | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Katima Mulilo Bridge.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | official_name = | other_name = | carries = | crosses = [[Zambezi River]] | locale = [[Katima Mulilo]], [[Namibia]]
[[Sesheke]], [[Zambia]] | owner = | maint = | id = | website = | architect = | designer = | engineering = | design = | material = | length = {{convert|900|m}} | width = | height = | mainspan = | spans = 19 | pierswater = | load = | clearance = | below = | life = | builder = [[Concor]] | fabricator = | begin = | complete = | cost = | open = | inaugurated = 13 May 2004 | toll = | traffic = | preceded = | followed = | heritage = | collapsed = | closed = | replaces = | map_cue = | map_image = | map_alt = | map_text = | map_width = | coordinates = {{Coord|17|28|18|S|24|14|59.73|E|region:TZ_type:landmark|display=it}} | lat = | long = | references = | extra = {{Location map | Namibia |label = |label_size = |alt = |relief = |position = right |background = |lon_dir = E |lat_dir = S |lat_deg = 17 |lat_min = 28 |lat_sec = 18 |lon_deg = 24 |lon_min = 14 |lon_sec = 59.73 |lat = |long = |mark = |marksize = |border = none |float = |width = |caption = Location in Namibia }} }} The '''Katima Mulilo Bridge''' (also known as ''Bridge 508'' in the Namibian Bridge Register) carries the [[TransCaprivi Highway]] over the [[Zambezi River]] between [[Katima Mulilo]], [[Namibia]] and [[Sesheke]], [[Zambia]]. It is a [[road]] bridge, completed in 2004, 900 metres long and with 19 spans.[http://www.klausdierks.com/Namibian_Roads/Zambezi_bridge.htm Website of] Dr. [[Klaus Dierks]] [http://www.klausdierks.com/FrontpageMain.html], first Deputy Minister for Works, Transport and Communication in independent Namibia, involved in the planning and negotiations for the bridge, accessed 15 February 2005. It links Namibia's [[Trans–Caprivi Highway]] to the Zambian road network, forming a section of the trade route from south-central Africa to the [[Atlantic]] known as the [[Walvis Bay]] Corridor. It is also intended to carry [[tourism|tourist]] traffic.[http://www.grnnet.gov.na/News/Archive/2004/may/week2/bridge_rpt.htm Speech of Dr. [[Sam Nujoma]]] at the bridge's opening ceremony, as published on the [http://www.grnnet.gov.na/ Government of Namibia Network] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121203072358/http://www.grnnet.gov.na/ |date=2012-12-03 }}, accessed 15 February 2005. Plans for the [[bridge]] were first considered in Namibia in 1982, and the number 508 was allocated to the project. However, the [[History of Namibia|occupying]] [[South Africa]]n government was opposed to the project, and only after Namibian independence was planning resumed in 1990. In 2002 the [[contract]] for construction was awarded to [[Concor]] of [[South Africa]] and [[Hochtief]] of [[Germany]], with the bridge completed on schedule in 2004. The bridge was constructed using the German technique of [[incremental launching]] (''Taktschiebe-Verfahren''), with the deck of the bridge constructed on location then [[hydraulics|hydraulically]] pushed segment-by-segment across the river. The bridge was officially opened by the [[President of Namibia]], Dr. [[Sam Nujoma]], and [[President of Zambia]], [[Levy Mwanawasa]] on 13 May 2004, in Katima Mulilo. == See also == * [[List of crossings of the Zambezi River]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.smec.com/Default.aspx?aProjId=941 Project Profile at SMEC website] [[Category:International bridges]] [[Category:Road bridges]] [[Category:Bridges in Zambia]] [[Category:Bridges in Namibia]] [[Category:Namibia–Zambia border crossings]] [[Category:Bridges completed in 2004]] [[Category:Bridges over the Zambezi River]] [[Category:2004 establishments in Zambia]] [[Category:2000s establishments in Namibia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Western Province, Zambia]] {{Africa-bridge-struct-stub}} {{Namibia-struct-stub}} {{Zambia-struct-stub}}

{{Cleanup|date=December 2009}}
The '''Kucong''' ({{zh|s=苦聪人|t=苦聰人|p=Kǔcōng rén}}) is an ethnic group in [[China]] and it is considered one of the poorest minorities in the country. There are around 80,000 Kucong people and they live in five other countries, namely [[Thailand]], [[Myanmar]], [[Vietnam]], [[Laos]], and the [[United States]], where at least 600 are living as migrants.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Peoples of the Buddhist World: A Christian Prayer Diary|last=Hattaway|first=Paul|publisher=William Carey Library|year=2004|isbn=1903689902|location=Pasadena, CA|pages=144}}</ref> The bulk of the population, however, live in the [[Mojiang]], [[Xinping]], and [[Mengla]] counties of China's Yunnan Province.
The Kucong found in [[Laos]] and are considered to be one the nation's more primitive groups. More than 3,000 Kucong inhabit at least 16 villages of northern part of the country. A subgroup of the Kucong in Laos are called Lahu Aga ('Bent Gourd Lahu') by other people because traditionally they wore a curved gourd around their necks. These are the reasons why the Kucong are often identified by some sources<ref>{{Cite book|title=An Ethnohistorical Dictionary of China|last=Olson|first=James|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=1998|isbn=0313288534|location=Westport, CT|pages=190}}</ref> as part of Lahu group. There are sources, however, that cite distinctions between the two minorities. These point to key differences such as in the case of their languages. Although closely related, Kucong and Lahu are far from mutually intelligible.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Atlas of Languages of Intercultural Communication in the Pacific, Asia, and the Americas|last=Wurm|first=Stephen|last2=Muhlhausler|first2=Peter|last3=Tryon|first3=Darrell|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|year=1996|isbn=3110134179|location=Berlin|pages=754}}</ref>
The Kucong are not recognized by the Chinese government as an official minority nationality, but they are officially being considered.<ref name="Gladney" /> The group has previously applied for a separate minority status but it was rejected in 1985. It is currently under the category of unclassified minorities in China.<ref name=":0" />
The people are considered as invisible people since they have little contact with other ethnic groups and they also seldom let traders see them when they sell their wares to buy some necessities. Their houses are small and narrow and a house consists of a single room without divisions and without windows. The fire is in the center, where the family members sleep with their livestock. Today, they still keep a semi-nomadic existence, living mainly from hunting and gathering; and government subsidies. Kucong children also have difficulty going to school because the medium of instruction in schools near the places they live in is Mandarin.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Negotiating Ethnicity in China: Citizenship as a Response to the State|last=Shih|first=Chih-yu|publisher=Routledge|year=2003|isbn=0415283728|location=London|pages=172}}</ref>
==References== <references> <ref name="Gladney"> {{ Citation | last=Gladney | first=Dru | title=Dislocating China : Reflections on Muslims, Minorities, and Other Subaltern Subjects | publisher=University of Chicago Press | year=2004 | page=9 | ISBN = 0-226-29775-6 }} </ref> </references>
==External links== * [http://www.ethnic-china.com/Kucong/kucongintro.htm Kucong] ethnic-china.com * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111003074140/http://www.millionelephants.com/UPGs/kucong.htm Kucong] millionelephants.com
{{Asia-ethno-group-stub}} {{Laos-stub}} {{China-stub}}

revision.text:
The globalization of [[National Hockey League]] has been occurring since its inception. The early years saw a largely Canadian league, with some Americans playing. As the league progressed it experienced an influx of European players, at first from Western European countries, such as Sweden. After the fall of Communism, players from Eastern European countries, such as the former Czechoslovakia and Soviet Union, joined the league. The NHL eventually saw fewer European players, but more players from Canada and the United States. Today the NHL has players from five continents. The following is a '''list of countries and the first person born there that played in the National Hockey League.''' These players are not necessarily the first citizen of each respective country to play in the NHL, as nationality is determined under a nation's [[nationality law]] and may differ. Additionally, some countries have had citizens play in the NHL, but have never had a ''native-born'' player reach the league. One current example of this is [[Australia]]; while the country saw its first citizen reach the league in 2017, said player ([[Nathan Walker]]) had been born in the United Kingdom. Most statistical sources in the sport follow the convention of the [[Hockey Hall of Fame]] in classifying players by the currently existing countries in which their birthplaces are located. ==Current countries== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" |- ! Country of birth || Name || Debut Year |- | [[Austria]] || [[Reinhard Divis]][http://vansunsportsblogs.com/2011/07/04/the-2011-invitees-part-one-in-a-two-part-epic/ The 2011 Invitees: Part One in a Two-Part Epic] || [[2001–02 NHL season|2001–02]][http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/pdisplay.php?pid=41826 Reinhard Divis] |- | [[The Bahamas]] || [[Andre Deveaux]][http://www.legendsofhockey.net/LegendsOfHockey/jsp/SearchPlayer.jsp?player=20721 Andre Deveaux] || [[2008–09 NHL season|2008–09]][http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/pdisplay.php?pid=55196 Andre Deveaux] |- | [[Belarus]] || [[Alexander Andrievsky]]Andrievsky was technically born in the [[Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic|Byelorussian SSR]] of the former [[Soviet Union|USSR]], which became the country of Belarus in 1991. || [[1992-93 NHL season|1992–93]][http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/pdisplay.php?pid=81 Alexander Andrijevski] |- | [[Belgium]] || [[Jan Benda]][http://www.sihrhockey.org/public_intl_hockey.cfm?letter=b&c=belg SIHR – Global Hockey Facts: Belgium] revision.text:
{{For|Republika Srpska and the Republic of Serb Krajina military operation in 1994|Operation Spider}} [[File:Operation Spider.png|thumbnail|300px|The logo published by IRGC's ''Gerdab.ir'' alongside the statement<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyberwarzone.com/iran-surveillance-spider-project-facebook-users/|first=Mohammad |last=Rafati |title=Iran Cyber Spider Project Against Facebook Users|date=January 31, 2015 |accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=cyberwarzone.com}}</ref>]] '''Operation Spider''' or '''Project Spider''' is a [[surveillance]] programme by [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]] (IRGC) to monitor [[Iran]]ian internet users on [[social media]] such as [[Facebook]]. The operation was publicized in January 2015 with a statement by IRGC's "The Center for Investigation of Organized Crime". The program is said to be expanding to [[Instagram]], [[Viber]], and [[WhatsApp]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/r-irans-guards-increase-monitoring-of-social-media-state-tv-2015-3|first=Sam |last=Wilkin |first2=Mehrdad |last2=Balali|title=Iran's elite Revolutionary Guards are ramping up domestic surveillance|date=March 2, 2015|accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref>
In 2016, Operation Spider II was used to detect Iranian models posting images of themselves online not wearing a headscarf. The models were subsequently charged with “promoting western promiscuity”.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/16/iranian-models-arrested-for-posting-pictures-without-headscarves/|first=Richard |last=Spencer |title=Iranian models arrested and forced to give public self-criticism for posting pictures without headscarves |accessdate=May 15, 2018|work=The Telegraph}}</ref> The Iranian models were arrested and forced to give public self-criticism for posting the pictures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/iran-arrests-8-people-spider-ii-operation-targeting-models-posing-online-without-2369545|first= Vishakha |last= Sonawane |title=Iran Arrests 8 People In Spider II Operation Targeting Models Posing Online Without Headscarves |accessdate=May 15, 2018|work=IB Times}}</ref>
== 2015 Arrests == Since September 2014, the IRGC intensified its review of [[Facebook]] pages, and that 350 Facebook pages managed by 36 individuals had been identified and 130 of them deleted from Facebook.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.iranhumanrights.org/2015/03/facebook-users-arrested/|title=Facebook Users Arrested, Others Will Be Arrested Soon, IRGC Warns|date=March 13, 2015|accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran }}</ref>
In January 2015, 12 Iranian Facebook users were arrested and 24 other citizens were summoned to answer questions about their Facebook activities.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.iranhumanrights.org/2015/02/facebook-arrests/|title=Iran’s IRGC Intensifies Crackdown on Facebook Users with 12 Arrests and 24 Summonses|date= February 5, 2015 |accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran }}</ref>
On January 31, a statement by the Center for Investigation of Organized Cyber Crimes was published that stated several Facebook users had been arrested in a surveillance project by the IRGC named “Operation Spider” that is aimed at identifying and rooting out Facebook pages and activities that spread “corruption” and western-inspired lifestyles. The statement also says they "received indirect and covert support from the Western governments and had targeted a remarkable number of Facebook users in the guise of cultural and social pages over a span of two years".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tasnimnews.com/English/Home/Single/638880|title=Iran Busts Facebook Band Involved in Criminal Acts |date=January 31, 2015|accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=[[Tasnim News Agency]]}}</ref> == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Portal bar|Iran|Internet|Computer security}} {{Cyberwarfare in Iran}} [[Category:Cyberwarfare in Iran]] [[Category:Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]] [[Category:Mass surveillance]] [[Category:Facebook]]

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Xiangyang |local = 天主教襄阳教区 |latin = Dioecesis Siamiamensis |country = China |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|Hankou]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|Hankou]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] |cathedral = |cocathedral = |area_km2 = |population = 1,163,824 |population_as_of = 1950 |catholics = 20,184 |catholics_percent= 1.7 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |metro_archbishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Xiangyang/Siangyang''' ({{lang-la|Siamiamen(sis)}}, {{zh|襄陽}}) is a [[suffragan]] Latin [[diocese]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|Archbishopric of Hankou]] in central China, yet it depends on the missionary [[Roman Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples]].
Its episcopal see is located in the city of [[Xiangyang]]. No statistics available.
Vacant since 1974, without [[Apostolic administrator]].
== History == * Established on May 25, 1936 as '''[[Apostolic Prefecture]] of Xiangyang''' 襄陽, on territory split off from the then [[Apostolic Vicariate of Laohekou]] 老河口 * May 10, 1951: Promoted as '''Diocese of Xiangyang''' 襄陽
== Ordinaries == ([[Roman Rite]]) <ref>http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/sian1.htm GCatholic.org</ref>
;''Apostolic Prefect of Xiangyang 襄陽 * Francis Yi Xuan-hua (Yi Hsüan-hua) (易宣化) (born China) (May 25, 1936 – May 10, 1951 ''see below'')
;''Suffragan Bishops of Xiangyang * [[Francis Yi Xuan-hua]] (Yi Hsüan-hua) (易宣化) (''see above'' May 10, 1951 – death 1974).

revision.text:
{{Taxation}} A '''withholding tax''', or a '''retention tax''', is an [[income tax]] to be paid to the government by the payer of the income rather than by the recipient of the income. The tax is thus withheld or deducted from the income due to the recipient. In most jurisdictions, withholding tax applies to [[employment]] income. Many jurisdictions also require withholding tax on payments of [[interest]] or [[dividend]]s. In most jurisdictions, there are additional withholding tax obligations if the recipient of the income is resident in a different jurisdiction, and in those circumstances withholding tax sometimes applies to [[royalties]], [[renting|rent]] or even the sale of [[real estate]]. Governments use withholding tax as a means to combat [[tax evasion]], and sometimes impose additional withholding tax requirements if the recipient has been delinquent in filing tax returns, or in industries where tax evasion is perceived to be common.
Typically the withholding tax is treated as a payment on account of the recipient's final tax liability, when the withholding is made in advance. It may be refunded if it is determined, when a [[wikt:tax return|tax return]] is filed, that the recipient's tax liability to the government which received the withholding tax is less than the tax withheld, or additional tax may be due if it is determined that the recipient's tax liability is more than the withholding tax. In some cases the withholding tax is treated as discharging the recipient's tax liability, and no tax return or additional tax is required. Such withholding is known as final withholding.
The amount of withholding tax on income payments other than employment income is usually a fixed percentage. In the case of employment income the amount of withholding tax is often based on an estimate of the employee's final tax liability, determined either by the employee or by the government.
==Basics== Some governments have written laws which require taxes to be paid before the money can be spent for any other purpose. This ensures the taxes will be paid first and will be paid on time, rather than risk the possibility that the tax-payer might [[default (finance)|default]] at the time when tax falls due in arrears.
Typically, withholding is required to be done by the employer of someone else, taking the tax payment funds out of the employee or contractor's salary or wages. The withheld taxes are then paid by the employer to the government body that requires payment, and applied to the account of the employee, if applicable. The employee may also be required by the government to file a tax return self-assessing one's tax and reporting withheld payments.
==Income taxes==
===Wage withholding=== {{see also|Payroll tax}} Most developed countries operate a wage withholding tax system. In some countries, [[subnational]] governments require wage withholding so that both national and subnational taxes may be withheld. In the [[Tax withholding in the United States|U.S.]],<ref>See U.S. [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS) [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p15.pdf Publication 15], which includes withholding tables for income tax. State requirements vary by state; for an example, see the New York state portal for [http://www.tax.ny.gov/bus/wt/wtidx.htm withholding tax].</ref> [[Payroll tax#Canada|Canada]],<ref>See [[Canada Revenue Agency]] [http://www.cra-arc.gc.ca/E/pub/tg/t4001/t4001-09e.pdf Publication T4001]. Canada Revenue Agency also provides significant online guidance accessible through a web [http://www.cra-arc.gc.ca/payroll/index.html index], including an online [http://www.cra-arc.gc.ca/esrvc-srvce/tx/bsnss/pdoc-eng.html payroll tax calculator].</ref> and others, the federal and most state or provincial governments, as well as some local governments, require such withholding for income taxes on payments by employers to employees. Income tax for the individual for the year is generally determined upon filing a tax return after the end of the year.
The amount withheld and paid by the employer to the government is applied as a prepayment of income taxes and is refundable if it exceeds the income tax liability determined on filing the tax return. In such systems, the employee generally must make a representation to the employer regarding factors that would influence the amount withheld.<ref>See, e.g., IRS [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/fw4.pdf Form W-4].</ref> Generally, the tax authorities publish guidelines for employers to use in determining the amount of income tax to withhold from wages.
The [[Payroll tax#United Kingdom|United Kingdom]]<ref>See [[HM Revenue and Customs]] (HMRC) [http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/intro/basics.htm PAYE for employers: the basics]</ref> and certain other jurisdictions operate a withholding tax system known as [[pay-as-you-earn tax|pay-as-you-earn]] (PAYE), although the term "withholding tax" is not commonly used in the UK. Unlike many other withholding tax systems, PAYE systems generally aim to collect all of an employee's tax liability through the withholding tax system, making an end of year tax return redundant. However, taxpayers with more complicated tax affairs must file tax returns.
[[Payroll tax#Australia|Australia]] operates a [[pay-as-you-go tax|pay-as-you-go]] (PAYG) system, which is similar to PAYE. The system applies only at the federal level, as the individual states do not collect income taxes.<ref>See the Australian Tax Office's [http://www.ato.gov.au/businesses/content.asp?doc=/content/31962.htm&pc=001/003/079/001/004&mnu=&mfp=&st=&cy=1 PAYG withholding] web page for details and tools.</ref>
===Other domestic withholding=== Some systems require that income taxes be withheld from certain payments other than wages made to domestic persons. [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] requires withholding of tax on payments of interest on deposits by banks and building societies to individuals.<ref>See Irish Tax & Customs [http://www.revenue.ie/en/tax/dirt/index.html Deposit Interest Retention Tax].</ref> The U.S. requires payers of dividends, interest, and other "reportable payments" to individuals to withhold tax on such payments in certain circumstances.<ref>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/3406- 26 USC 3406], Backup Withholding. Withholding applies to individuals who have not provided the payee a tax identification number or failed to certify that they are is subject to backup withholding or with respect to whom the IRS has notified the payee that backup withholding applies. The rate of withholding tax is the fourth lowest rate of tax for individuals.</ref> [[Australia]] requires payers of interest, dividends and other payments to withhold an amount when the payee does not provide a [[tax file number]] or [[Australian Business Number]] to the payer. [[India]] enforces withholding tax also on payments between companies and not just from companies to individuals, under the [[Tax Deducted at Source|TDS]] system. (Since April 2016, the [[United Kingdom]] has discontinued withholding tax on interest and dividends, though in some cases this income will become liable for taxation through other means).<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/dividend-allowance-factsheet/dividend-allowance-factsheet Dividend Allowance factsheet ]] [[HMRC]], 17 August 2015</ref>
==Social insurance taxes (social security)== Many countries (and/or subdivisions thereof) have social insurance systems that require payment of taxes for retirement annuities and medical coverage for retirees. Most such systems require that employers pay a tax to cover such benefits.<ref>See for example [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/3111- 26 USC 3111]; ATO [http://www.ato.gov.au/content/downloads/SPR00108513n71038.pdf Publication 71038], Super: What employers need to know. Some systems, for example, [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]] levy a [http://www.osr.nsw.gov.au/taxes/payroll/ payroll tax] independently of a social insurance system.</ref> Some systems also require that employees pay such taxes.<ref>See, for example, [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/3102- 26 USC 3102].</ref>
Where the employees are required to pay the tax, it is generally withheld from the payment of wages and paid by the employer to the government. Social insurance tax rates may be different for employers than for employees. Most systems provide an upper limit on the amount of wages subject to social insurance taxes.<ref>These limits may vary by country and year. For 2009, the U.S. income limit on the retirement portion (6.2%) of social security tax was $106,800, versus $102,000 for 2008, and there was no limit on the medicare portion (1.45%) of the tax; see Publication 15, supra. Canadian wages subject to [[Canada Pension Plan]] were limited to $46,390 of the excess over $3,500 for 2009, at a tax rate of 4.95%; see Publication T4001, supra. UK [http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/nitables/ca38.pdf National Insurance contributions] are due for earnings above the Earnings Threshold (£110 weekly) up to a limit that varies depending on other coverage.</ref>
==International withholding== Most countries require payers of interest, dividends and royalties to non-resident payees (generally, if a non-domestic postal address is in the payers records) withhold from such payment an amount at a specific rate.<ref>See, e.g., [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/html/uscode26/usc_sup_01_26_10_A_20_3_30_A.html 26 USC 1441-1446], IRS Publication 515, CRA Publication [http://www.cra-arc.gc.ca/E/pub/tg/t4061/t4061-09e.pdf T4061].</ref> Payments of rent may also be subject to withholding tax or may be taxed as business income.<ref>For example, U.S. rules provide that rentals that rise to the level of a trade or business are not subject to withholding taxes, but other rental income may be subject to 30% withholding tax. An election may be available under [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/871- 26 USC 871(d)] or an applicable [[tax treaty]].</ref> The amounts may vary by type of income. A few jurisdictions treat fees paid for technical consulting services as royalties subject to withholding of tax.{{Citation needed|reason=India citation needed|date=September 2011}}{{Citation needed|reason=Pakistan citation needed|date=September 2011}} Income [[tax treaties]] may reduce the amount of tax for particular types of income paid from one country to residents of the other country.
Some countries require withholding by the purchaser of real property. The U.S. also imposes a 10% withholding tax on the gross sales price of a U.S. real property interest unless advance IRS approval is obtained for a lower rate.<ref>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/897- 26 USC 897] and [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/1445- 26 USC 1445]. The lower rate of withholding is requested by filing IRS [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f8288b.pdf Form 8288-B] by the sale closing date.</ref> Canada imposes similar rules for 25% withholding, and withholding on sale of business real property is 50% of the price, but may be reduced on application.
The European Union has issued directives prohibiting taxation on companies by one member state of dividends from subsidiaries in other member state,<ref>The [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31990L0435:EN:HTML parent/subsidiary directive].</ref> except in some cases,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=t0Z_Jla7D1gC&dq=salvador+trinxet&source=bl&ots=4y2M7NB-c4&sig=xosb_2rlC-Q3B5DuIYCkdsgXezc&hl=es&sa=X&ei=wQFNUPDjI4HQ9ASr_ICoBA&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBTgK [[Parent Subsidiary Directive]], by Salvador Trinxet Llorca]</ref> interest on debt obligations, or royalties<ref>The [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32003L0049:en:HTML [[interest and royalties directive]]].</ref> received by a resident of another member nation.
Procedures vary for obtaining reduced withholding tax under income tax treaties. Procedures for recovery of excess amounts withheld vary by jurisdiction. In some, recovery is made by filing a tax return for the year in which the income was received. Time limits for recovery vary greatly.
Taxes withheld may be eligible for a [[foreign tax credit]] in the payee's home country.
==Remittance to tax authorities== Most withholding tax systems require withheld taxes to be remitted to tax authorities within specified time limits, which time limits may vary with the withheld amount. Remittance by [[electronic funds transfer]] may be required<ref>The U.S. requires remittance electronically within no later than the following business day when the balance of unremitted amounts exceeds $100,000, and other thresholds apply; see IRS Publication 15, supra, p. 23. Canada requires remittance within three business days of the end of the quarter-monthly period in which withholding occurs for Threshold 2 remitters; see CRA Publication T-4001, supra., p. 3.</ref> or preferred.
Penalties for delay or failure to remit withheld taxes to tax authorities can be severe.<ref>Penalties of up to 100% may be assessed against a withholding agent under [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/6672- 26 USC 6672] for intentional failure to withhold and remit. The penalty may be assessed against any person, including a corporate officer or employee, having custody or control of the funds.</ref> The sums withheld by a business is regarded as a debt to the tax authority, so that on bankruptcy of the business the tax authority stands as an unsecured creditor; however, sometimes the tax authority has legislative priority over other creditors.
==Reporting== Nearly all systems imposing withholding tax requirements also require reporting of amounts withheld in a specified manner. Copies of such reporting are usually required to be provided to both the person on whom the tax is imposed and to the levying government.<ref>See, for example, IRS Form W-2 and CRA Form T4 with respect to employees, and IRS Form 1042 and CRA Form NR4 with respect to payments to foreign persons.</ref> Reporting is generally required annually for amounts withheld with respect to wages. Reporting requirements for other payments vary, with some jurisdictions requiring annual reporting and others requiring reporting within a specified period after the withholding occurs.
